awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Statistical Methods for RNA-seq Based Transcriptomic Analysis of Macrophage Function in Spinal Cord Injury
awd_abstract_narration:
Spinal cord injury causes functional impairment via the primary mechanical injury, followed by subsequent secondary injury mechanisms at cellular levels.  Most research has focused on understanding the mechanisms of secondary injury since it corresponds to functional deficits. Inflammation is a principal mediator of the secondary injury cascade, with macrophages contributing profoundly to the secondary injury.  Macrophages, one of the most important type of immune cells, migrate towards the injured spinal cord and engulf myelin debris that is generated at injury onset to form myelin-laden macrophages. In this project, the investigators will utilize RNA sequencing, a powerful method for analyzing global gene expression levels, and develop new statistical approaches to address biological questions related to how myelin-laden macrophages amplify inflammatory response and promote secondary injury. These studies will help researchers understand molecular mechanisms for spinal cord injury and shed new light on the treatment by targeting myelin-laden macrophages. 

This project aims to answer important questions regarding the mechanisms of secondary injury through the integration of new statistical methods and cutting-edge biological techniques. The central hypothesis is that myelin-laden macrophages in the injured spinal cord promote a local pathologic process and distal organ dysfunction. Specifically, the investigators will determine their molecular patterns and functions, study whether myelin-laden macrophages released extracellular vesicles (exosomes) carry microRNAs from myelin debris to recipient cells and then regulate their functions, and investigate whether these exosomes can enter the bloodstream and contribute to systemic inflammatory response syndrome and distal organ dysfunction. New statistical tools will be developed to analyze large datasets of microRNA sequencing and mRNA sequencing from multiple cell types and time points. In particular, novel robust statistical techniques are proposed to answer the following important questions: how to uniformly and robustly estimate large-scale gene expressions; how to compare them reliably across multiple phenotypes and measured across different platforms; how to accurately identify microRNAs' mRNA targets via sparse regression; how to use quantitative tools for studies of molecular mechanisms and comparisons of gene expression networks; how to control false discovery rate under general dependence; how to perform robust variable selection; how to estimate the size of spurious correlations.  The proposed methods will be applied to newly collected, as well as existing data to answer the biological questions related to spinal cord injury.  The project will integrate research and education by involving undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, creating new datasets, and developing publicly available software.  Students from underrepresented groups will be trained as part of this project.  The results will be disseminated broadly through presentations at seminars, conferences, and professional association meetings.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Spinal cord injury causes functional impairment via the primary injury and subsequent secondary injury mechanisms. Most research has focussed on understanding the mechanisms of secondary injury because it corresponds to function deficits.  Inflammation is a principal mediator of the secondary injury cascade, with macrophages  contributing profoundly to the secondary injury. This project answered important questions regarding the mechanisms of secondary injury through the integration of new statistical methods and cutting-edge biological techniques. The central hypothesis is that mye-Microphages in the injured spinal cord promote a local pathologic process and distal organ dysfunction.  To answer the question, the collaborative Pl generated large datasets of miRNA-sequencing  and mRNA-sequencing from multiple cell types and time points. Such large quantities of complex data and underlying specificity of biological problems prompted new challenges in developing robust and reliable statistics tools for analysis.

Novel robust statistical techniques were developped to answer the following important questions: how to uniformly estimating large-scale gene expressions; how to compare them reliably across multiple phenotypes and measured across different platforms; how to accurately identify miRNAs' mRNA targets via sparse regression; how to use quantitative tools for studies of molecular mechanisms and comparisons of gene expression networks; how to control false discovery rate under general dependence; how to do robust variable selections and classifications; how large the maximum spurious correlations for both continuous and binary responses can be. These newly proposed methods were applied to the  RNA-seq data to answer the biological questions for spinal core injury and  addressed biological questions related to how Microphage function change promotes the pathology of spinal core injury.

Specifically,  we developed robust statistical methods for selecting differently expressed genes in high-dimensions with control of false discovery rate under co-expressions environments. We also developped robust covariance estimation, dependency networks and graphs that allow us to conduct robust inferece on miRNA-mRNA networks and introduced conditional independence tests and dependent graphs and networks.  We further developped other  big data techniques that include  robust sparse high-dimensional regression and classification using robustified covariates, and distributions of spurious correlations. The  developped  novel robust statistical techniques and related algorithms can also be applied to other biological and engineering problems, including robust high-dimensional statistics for Big Data analytics.

This project output over 30 publications in top statistical and other scientific journals, covering a wide range of topics, from statistical machine learning and networks to robust large-scale statistical inference and dependent graphs.  The grant benefited directly and indirectly 28 Ph.D. students (10 females, 18 graduated, 10 ongoing).  In addition, 22 senior theses (10 females) for undergraduates have been directed, all their theses related to using statistical machine learning methods to address important societal problems, particularly in finance, economics, and other decision sciences. Three (1 female) high-school senior students completed an internship, contributed to and benefited from the research.


Last Modified: 08/12/2023
Modified by: Jianqing Fan
